Award.AwardTitle: AF: Small: Quantitative and Algorithmic Aspects of Semi-algebraic Sets and Partitions

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
"Divide and conquer," a time-honored technique in computer science and
mathematics, partitions a problem into smaller pieces to make it
easier to solve. This project deepens the study of partitioning in two
directions, both in the context of semi-algebraic geometry -- which is
the study of geometric and topological properties of sets defined by
real polynomial equalities and inequalities.

The first direction is to systematize polynomial partitioning, which
has recently become a powerful tool capable of tackling many
long-standing open questions in the area of incidence geometry. In
computational geometry, the space or sets being partitioned are often
complex but partitioning is by simple objects: splitting by planes or
cutting into trapezoids. Polynomial partitioning allows high degree
cutting polynomials, necessitating more precise degree-based upper
bounds on the topology of semi-algebraic sets and real varieties than
the ones known before, and leading to a very fruitful interaction
between the fields of real algebraic geometry and discrete geometry.
The PI will develop new techniques in semi-algebraic geometry to meet
the new demands imposed on the field by the developments in discrete
geometry, and develop a new theory of polynomial partitioning that can
systematize their study and lead to new applications as well.

The second is to generalize quantitative and algorithmic
semi-algebraic geometry to a much more general and geometric setting
-- the category of constructible sheaves. Constructible sheaves come
with an underlying semi-algebraic partition (on whose elements the
stalks of the sheaf are locally constant). Kashiwara and Schapira
proved a fundamental theorem on the stability of this category under
the six standard sheaf operations (analogous to Tarski-Seidenberg
principle for semi-algebraic sets). The PI will study the quantitative
and algorithmic questions related to constructible sheaves. The
complexity upper bounds and algorithmic results would have wide
applications.

The project will have impact in several areas of mathematics and
computation -- including quantitative and algorithmic semi-algebraic
geometry, discrete and computational geometry, computational
complexity theory and quantitative study of the solutions to linear
systems of partial differential equations. The project will train a
graduate student and a postdoctoral researcher in quantitative and
algorithmic real algebraic geometry and its modern applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Semi-algebraic geometry deals with the study of the topology and geometry of semi-algebraic sets i.e. subsets of finite dimensional real space defined by first order formulas with atoms which are polynomial equalities and inequalities. Since semi-algebraic  sets are ubiquitous in real life (inside and outside of mathematics)  study of their quantitative and algorithmic properties are increasing every day. Unfortunately, in general the basic algorithmic problems in semi-algebraic geometry tend to have high complexity  -- to solve them exactly usually require algorithms whose complexity in the worst case is singly exponential in the dimension. This is related to the fact that semi-algebraic sets while being easy to define can become topologically  complicated quite quickly. This feature sometimes restrict the application of the rich algorithmic theory of semi-algebraic sets and it is thus important to concentrate on special situations of practical relevance where the complexity is better controlled.


The results obtained during this project has led to deepening of our understanding of the topological complexities of semi-algebraic sets as well as to the development of more efficient algorithms for computing topological as well as representation-theoretic invariants of semi-algebraic sets. In particular, semi-algebraic sets  defined by symmetric polynomials were studied from the topological, representation-theoretic,  as well as  algorithmic viewpoints.

Several new results were obtained.  We obtained an  algorithm with polynomial complexity  for computing the equivariant Betti numbers of such sets (joint work with C. Riener).  We also obtained very general bounds on the Betti numbers of semi-algebraic sets unifying several different  prior results under a single framework (joint work with A. Rizzie). Another outcome of the project was a new result  connecting incidence combinatorics with o-minimal geometry -- namely, an o-minimal version of the famous  Szemeredi-Trotter theorem about line-point incidences  (joint work with O. Raz).   This work connects o-minimal structures with combinatorics in a novel way and. might lead to interesting future developments.  Finally, we initiated the study of complexity in a categorical  setting and proved several results on functor complexity (joint work with Umut Isik). This work can potentially unify different notions of  "complexity" -- such as Turing complexity, Blum-Shub-Smale complexity etc. under a single categorical framework, and provide categorical analogs for some of the basic open problems in complexity theory (such as P vs NP). 

The results obtained in this project lie at the boundary of real algebraic geometry, symbolic algorithms, model theory, complexity theory  and combinatorics -- and have the potential to have impact on each of these fields. The PI taught several graduate level courses on the material -- including a course on model theory and a course on basic representation theory.The PI organized several workshops including one at the FoCM conference in Barcelona and smaller mini-conferences at Purdue which led to a lot of research interactions.Two Phd students partially supported by the project graduated with doctoral degrees.
